lesson_html:
Dictionaries in Python are similar to C# 'Dictionary' - they are key-value data structures that allow fast lookups and storage of related information.

Key characteristics of Python dictionaries:

  • Created using curly braces {} or dict() constructor
  • Keys must be immutable (strings, numbers, tuples)
  • Values can be of any type
  • Unordered collection

Basic Dictionary Operations

# Creating a dictionary student = {'name': 'Alice', 'age': 22, 'grades': [85, 90, 88]} # Accessing values print(student['name']) # 'Alice' # Adding/Updating values student['major'] = 'Computer Science' student['age'] = 23 # Checking key existence if 'name' in student: print('Name found')

Unlike C# dictionaries, Python dictionaries have built-in methods like .get() for safe key access and .keys(), .values(), .items() for iteration.
